papers.abstract: Over the past decade, podcasting has grown into one of the most important media forms in the world. This article argues that podcasting’s unique technical affordances — particularly RSS feeds and user-entered metadata — open up productive methods for exploring the cultural practices and meanings of the medium. We share three different methods for studying RSS feeds and podcast metadata: 1) visualizing how topics and keywords trend over time; 2) visualizing networks of commonly associated keywords entered by podcasters; and 3) analyzing norms and common practices for the duration of podcasts (as a time-based media format, podcasting is unusual in that it is not bound by the programming schedules and technical limitations that provide strict parameters for most audiovisual forms). The methods and preliminary results reveal how metadata can function as a surrogate for studying large collections of time-based media objects. Yet our study also shows that, when it comes to born digital media, the metadata are never fully separate from the objects they describe. We argue that future work in AV in DH needs to delineate between methods best suited for digitized media collections compared to those most appropriate for born digital media collections.

This article argues that podcasting’s unique technical affordances — particularly RSS feeds and user-entered metadata — open up productive methods for exploring the cultural practices and meanings of the medium.

Method: Technical affordances, particularly RSS feeds and user-entered metadata

visualizing networks of commonly associated keywords entered by podcasters

events.Text: The methods and preliminary results reveal how metadata can function as a surrogate for studying large collections of time-based media objects. Yet our study also shows that, when it comes to born digital media, the metadata are never fully separate from the objects they describe.

Context: Metadata can function as a surrogate for studying large collections of time-based media objects
Purpose: To understand how metadata can function as a surrogate for studying large collections of time-based media objects
Results: how metadata can function as a surrogate for studying large collections of time-based media objects
when it comes to born digital media, the metadata are never fully separate from the objects they describe
Analysis: This suggests that metadata are integrated with the objects they describe, particularly in the case of born digital media
Challenge: The metadata are never fully separate from the objects they describe
Implications: Understanding how metadata interacts with media objects has broader implications for preservation, management, and access
Future research can build upon these insights to refine handling strategies
Contradictions: The finding contradicts the assumption that metadata operates separately from the objects it describes

events.Text: We argue that future work in AV in DH needs to delineate between methods best suited for digitized media collections compared to those most appropriate for born digital media collections.

Purpose: improving categorization based on collection types
Analysis: interpreting these findings suggests that current methods may vary depending on the type of data

papers.abstract: This paper introduces Coleto, an automatic collation tool for the comparison of variant texts in English, German, or French, which separates edits from variant texts so that textual changes can be classified and contextualized. Coleto’s proposed methodology for the classification of edits in variants includes: major/minor expansion, major/minor condensation, changes to numbers and whitespace, and common orthographic features. From this classification schema, Coleto generates: an aligned table of edits in the variants, visualizations of the frequency of classified edits, and a visualization of edit density across the progression of the texts. As a sample use case, we present mixed-method analyses of Andy Weir’s science fiction bestseller, The Martian, aided by Coleto’s functions and generated outputs.

events.Text: This paper introduces Coleto, an automatic collation tool for the comparison of variant texts in English, German, or French, which separates edits from variant texts so that textual changes can be classified and contextualized.

Secondary Object: variant texts in English, German, or French
